subject: Re: [junit] Re: Individual tests ok, problem in a suite
msgSnippet: ... Sadly, I have a counter-example [1]. [Not counting the degenerate cases where I wrote the compiler.] [1] When Pop11 gained full lexical scoping, I
messageBody:
On Saturday 14 May 2005 00:03, Cedric Beust wrote:
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> >
> > The lesson here is to restrict variable declarations to the
> > smallest scope that you can get away with.
>
> The other lesson is: if you think you found a bug in HashMap, you are most
> likely wrong :-)
>
> (which is a variant of the older saying: the bug is always in your code,
> never in the compiler)

Sadly, I have a counter-example [1].

[Not counting the degenerate cases where I wrote the compiler.]

[1] When Pop11 gained full lexical scoping, I immediately wrote a
perfectly straighforward clump of nexted procedures that broke
the compiler. Feer My Lexikal Skillz!

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
"The compiler is free to insert padding because it makes the struct
look bigger and scares away predators." [Keith Thompson, comp.lang.c]
